contents.title: My Journey from System Admin to Senior DevOps Engineer
contents.description: How I transitioned from traditional system administration to modern DevOps practices and cloud engineering

children.value: My Journey from System Admin to Senior DevOps Engineer

The transition from traditional system administration to DevOps engineering wasn't just a career change for me—it was a complete mindset shift that transformed how I approach technology, automation, and problem-solving.
Back in 2016, I started my career as a System Administrator. My daily routine involved:
- Waiting for things to break, then fixing them
- Separate teams for development and operations
While these skills were valuable, I quickly realized that the industry was moving toward something much more powerful and efficient.

The turning point came when I witnessed my first automated deployment pipeline. Watching code move from development to production without manual intervention was like seeing magic. That's when I knew I had to learn DevOps.
Key Learning Areas I Focused On:
The transition wasn't smooth sailing. Here are the major challenges:
The DevOps ecosystem is vast. I felt overwhelmed trying to learn everything at once.
I focused on one tool at a time and built practical projects.
Some teams were resistant to change from traditional methods.
I demonstrated value through small wins and gradual improvements.
Moving from a traditional role to a modern DevOps position made me question my abilities.
Continuous learning and contributing to open-source projects built my confidence.

contents.title: Building Scalable Cloud Infrastructure with Terraform
contents.description: A comprehensive guide to designing and implementing Infrastructure as Code using Terraform for multi-cloud environments

children.value: Building Scalable Cloud Infrastructure with Terraform

Infrastructure as Code (IaC) has revolutionized how we manage and deploy cloud resources. In this comprehensive guide, I'll share my experience building scalable, maintainable infrastructure using Terraform across multiple cloud providers.
After working with various IaC tools, Terraform stands out for several reasons:
- Single tool for AWS, Azure, GCP
- Describe what you want, not how to get there
Here's the folder structure I use for large-scale Terraform projects:

contents.title: Game Development as a DevOps Engineer: Building My First Unity Game
contents.description: How I applied DevOps principles to game development and what I learned building my first indie game

children.value: Game Development as a DevOps Engineer: Building My First Unity Game

As a DevOps engineer, I spend my days automating deployments, managing cloud infrastructure, and optimizing system performance. But in my spare time, I dive into a completely different world: game development. Here's my journey building my first Unity game and how my DevOps background both helped and hindered the process.
You might wonder why a DevOps engineer would venture into game development. For me, it started as a creative outlet:
- Unlike infrastructure code, games are visual and interactive
- Game logic requires a different type of thinking
- Learning something completely outside my expertise
- A fun escape from the technical demands of DevOps work
My first game is a simple 2D platformer called "Cloud Jumper" (yes, the DevOps influence is obvious). The concept:
A character jumping between cloud platforms in the sky
Simple jump controls, collectible items, obstacle avoidance
Coming from a DevOps background, I immediately set up proper Git workflows:

I approached game architecture like system architecture - modular, scalable, and maintainable.
My DevOps instincts kicked in, and I spent too much time building "scalable" systems for a simple game:
I spent weeks researching the "best" architecture patterns instead of just building the game.
I tried to automate everything, including art asset optimization and level generation, when manual work would have been faster.
The core challenge was creating responsive player movement:
Implementing reliable ground detection was trickier than expected:

Started with Unity Asset Store freebies

I applied software design principles to level design:
- Visual and audio cues for player actions
- Don't introduce new rules without context
- Each level section should be independently playable
My systems background helped with optimization:
I treated game deployment like any other software release:
Separate builds for testing and production
Published to itch.io with proper CI/CD
Not everything needs to be automated
Technical skills alone aren't enough for good games
Even personal projects need scope management
Technical excellence doesn't guarantee fun gameplay
My first game taught me that game development and DevOps share many principles but require different mindsets. I'm planning my next project with these insights:
Focus on gameplay first, optimization later
Investing time in learning basic art skills
Targeting mobile platforms for broader reach
The complete source code is available on GitHub:

Building my first Unity game as a DevOps engineer was both challenging and rewarding. While my technical background provided valuable skills for project management, testing, and deployment, I had to learn to balance technical perfectionism with creative pragmatism.
The experience reminded me why I love technology: it's not just about optimizing systems or managing infrastructure—it's about creating experiences and solving problems in new ways.
If you're a fellow DevOps engineer interested in game development, my advice is simple: start small, focus on fun, and don't let your perfectionist instincts slow you down too much.
